awards.title: Academy of Management 2016 Careers Division Best Symposium Award
awards.description: The symposium entitled “Not my breach! Innovative ways to study psychological contract breach and effects on meaningfulness” was selected by an independent jury from a total of 3 contenders that had been nominated. Presenters of the four papers in the well-attended symposium were Eloisa Federici, Matthijs Bal, Yannick Griep, Maria Tomprou and Kevin Henderson.

awards.description: Excellent Graduate Award in recognition of my academic achievements

profile_positions.description: Understanding in a systematic and data-driven way behaviours in the workplace, in order to identify, assess and mitigate risks and support evidence-based decision-making. Building and executing behavioural risk assessments, to identify and analyse behavioural risks and their drivers by means of quantitative and qualitative methodologies of data collection and data analysis techniques (e.g., surveys, interviews, focus groups, observations). Developing theoretical framework underlying the assessments. Carrying out large-scale projects in different levels/areas/countries of the organisation. Monitoring organisational risk culture by developing and maintaining dashboard and related data sources and indicators.
profile_positions.title: Research & Advice Professional | Risk Culture & Behavioural Risk

profile_positions.company: University of Amsterdam - Amsterdam Business School
profile_positions.description:
As a lecturer I was responsible of coordinating and teaching different Master courses on research methods (quantitative data analysis techniques, research designs, and surveys). First Supervisor of Master thesis projects.

Thesis workshop survey design. Learning goals: Learn how to design, develop, and conduct survey-based studies. Course content: Quantitative research design features, experimental/correlational design, conceptual model, research hypotheses, sampling techniques, validity and reliability of measures, how to build and administer a questionnaire.

Thesis workshop quantitative data analysis. Learning goals: Learn how to conduct multivariate analysis techniques in SPSS and report the results. Course content: factor analysis, analysis of variance, multiple regression, test of conditional and indirect effects.
profile_positions.title: Lecturer

profile_positions.company: University of Amsterdam - Amsterdam Business School
profile_positions.description:
Research:
I was part of EDUWORKS (Initial Training Network, Marie Skłodowska-Curie actions FP7 of the European Commissions), an international consortium with the objective to train talented early-stage researchers in the socioeconomic and psychological dynamics of the labour supply and demand matching processes at aggregated and dis-aggregated levels. 

Research topics: HRM practices, employment relationship, self-regulatory behaviors, adaptability. Dissertation title: "The pursuit of an employment relationship: Managing people in a flexible labor market". 

Teaching:
- Thesis Workshop Quantitative Data Analysis: Multivariate analysis techniques in SPSS (e.g., factor analysis, analysis of variance, multiple regression, test of conditional and indirect effects).
- Thesis Workshop Survey Design: Quantitative research design features (e.g., design types, hypotheses, sampling techniques, validity and reliability of measures, how to build and administer a questionnaire).
- Thesis Workshop Qualitative Research - Case study, Thesis Research Methods: Qualitative research design features (e.g., case study types, data sources, validity, reliability, how to conduct interviews, data condensation, data display, data interpretation).
- First Supervisor of Bachelor and Master thesis projects.
profile_positions.title: PhD Candidate, Marie Curie ITN Fellow
